 Implemented Algorithms ======================

  • Slow start and congestion avoidance
  • Silly window avoidance (RFC1122, section 4.2.3.4)
  • Nagle's algorithm (can be turned off, default: on) (RFC1122, section 4.2.3.4)
  • Karn's algorithm (no RTT measurement during retransmission)
  • Fast retransmission and recovery (can be turned off, default: on)
  • RTT measurement with TS option according to RFC 1323 (can be turned off, default: on).

Member Function Documentation

int tcpipsend::act ( void   ) 

Implemented Algorithms ======================

  • Slow start and congestion avoidance
  • Silly window avoidance (RFC1122, section 4.2.3.4)
  • Nagle's algorithm (can be turned off, default: on) (RFC1122, section 4.2.3.4)
  • Karn's algorithm (no RTT measurement during retransmission)
  • Fast retransmission and recovery (can be turned off, default: on)
  • RTT measurement with TS option according to RFC 1323 (can be turned off, default: on).

Per packet sent, a processing delay of PROCTIM is included. The exact value is a random value between PROCTIM and 1.1 times PROCTIM. This avoids synchronisation effects between different TCP connections.

NOT Implemented =============== Timer for zero window probe: if the ACK opening the window again is lost, then the connection falls asleep forever.

Central Routines ================ calc_send(): Is always called when we possibly can transmit new data. Checks whether new data can be sent (silly window avoidance and Nagle's algorithm) and segments data according to MSS. Packets are enqueued in the output queue (which models the processing delay) via queue_pkt().

queue_pkt(): Creates a packet and enqueues it in the output queue. Provided that no packets are already waiting in the queue, and that we can send (not stopped by succeeding network object), the process send_pkt() is woken up.

send_pkt(): Is called to really emit a packet. Is always invoked via the timer modelling the processing delay. This timer is activated by queue_pkt(), and upon receipt of a start signal (in case we wanted to send and have been stopped). Send_pkt() itself reactivates the timer if the packet just sent was not the last in the queue and we are allowed to continue.

process_ack(): Processes incoming acknowledges. Includes code for:

  • fast retransmission / recovery
  • receiver window update
  • algorithm for opening congestion window (slow start and congestion avoidance)
  • calculation of new RTO estimate (only in case of acknowleding new data) The retransmission timer is stopped, and restarted provided there is something on the way. If something has changed, calc_send() is called.

Problems ======== There is a general problem with the combination of processing queue and start- stop protocol. If the successor stops the module, then currently only the process of send_ptk() is stopped. Calc_send(), however, can continue to send. The result is that the processing queue acts like a large network buffer: the queue is filled until the window limit is reached. Proposal: Set a threshold for the length of the processing queue. If it is reached, calc_send() returns and sets the flag (only if not a retransmission). If the flag is set and send_pkt() reduces the queue length below the threshold, calc_send() is called again. Included (0.5.11.96, MBau)

  • marked with ifdef PROCQTHRESH,
  • the threshold is procqThresh = 2 (init())

Smaller detailed problems are marked in the code with "###". Additionally, they are labeled with Px_ (x is the number).

  • P1_: Why is fast retransm not done when rt_timer not active ? Since RT timer off implicitely means that there is nothing on the way (also could test una == nxt)
  • P2_: should we open cwnd and restart the retransmision timer when receiving an ACK which does not acknowledge new data but only changes the wnd?
  • P3_: appearently, we take one tick too much when calculating a new RTO.
  • P4_: if we got new data acked, is it then possible that the ack is larger than nxt ? Yes. If we had e.g a RTO, reset nxt, and now receive the ACK we were waiting for.
  • P5_: which role does the seq number of an ACK play ?
  • P6_: why is cwnd only opened in case wnd < cwnd ?
  • P7_: how can it be that the seq of the data in the input buffer is lower than nxt ? It should NOT be possible.
  • P9_: we should set max_sent when really sending a packet in send_pkt().
  • P10_: should we start the retransmission timer when enqueueing a packet in the output queue, or rather when really sending it ?
  • P11_: reduce ssthresh with fast retransmission? YESSSS ...: otherwise we would re-reach the congestion region immediately, and probably fast retransmission then will fail (too much will be lost)
